bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, June 28, 1953

div1.p: Tate responds to some of Truby's questions about gratuities, Martinez, and the problem of consecutive case numbers.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, June 28, 1953
div1.opener:
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley 3, Calif.
June 28, 1953
Dear General Truby:
div1.p:
As you asked my opinion regarding the in-
cluding of gratuities as part of the cost, I would think it is
difficult to say, as there are two distinct ways of considering
it. One could argue it ad infinitum and reach no conclusion.
Really, I think you have solved it admirably by showing the
amount so expended and then deducting from the total. Your way
one can see all the costs and take their choice as to including
the gratuities or not. That solves it.

About the Martinez question, I still think that he was
so commonly known by his middle name of Martinez, even to Major
Reed, that his last name was frequently forgotten.

Don't you think that some of the differences in consecu-
tive case numbers could have been caused by some using the date
of test, (application of mosquito or blood) and others, as I do,
the date of attack and admittance to Y. F. Ward? Of course, my
sole authority is a photostat of the Epidemic List sent to the
Surgeon General, and I would consider that to be correct.

Of course you may send any of my letters to Doctor Hench
if you desire. I can't imagine them being of any interest to
him as he desires only factual statements, and with his research
abilities, knows more about these things than I do. Yet--I feel
that though you and I may not be able to make every name and
date syncronize into an exact statement on everything and say:
“This is it,” still we were there. We know things we cannot prove.
For instance, someone sees the play, “Yellow Jack” and believes
(2)
that the Cuban part fairly presents what transpired there
and that the imitation Rudyard Kipling characters really repre-
sent the volunteers. But anyone who was there knows this play
is a poor caricature.

Well, I guess I've answered all your questions to the
best of my ability and am flattered that you should consult me
regarding them. Please let me know how things turn out, and
always call on me if you really think there is any way I can
be of assistance.
